5.51.text:
Ladies and gentlemen could you please take
your seats. Thank you, before we start I'd

6.93.text:
like to acknowledge the traditional custodians
of this land and pay our respects to the elders

12.60.text:
both past and present and future of the Turrbal
Tribe. I'm Peter Switzer, I'm your MC for

18.85.text:
today and I'd like to welcome you to the 2014
Queensland Small Business Week. And that's

25.36.text:
for joining us in this beautiful Ithaca Auditorium
in the City Hall. Of course I'd like to welcome

31.66.text:
the Premier Campbell Newman, thanks for coming
along today and distinguished guests. Of course

37.25.text:
I know the Premier is here for small business.
This is what this week's about and Queensland

43.13.text:
I think is the grand central of small business.
I know that, I get the feedback from small

47.79.text:
business people and they agree with me and
they even contact me when they don't agree

51.64.text:
with me. But certainly this is the place where
when Queensland small business is rocking

56.78.text:
I have a very positive attitude towards the
Australian economy. I think that's actually

60.95.text:
happening right now. And so I'm really glad
to be a part of this week. I should say to

67.19.text:
you many people might know you, or know me
because of my journalism in either the Weekend

72.01.text:
Australian or on a television show the Switzer
Program on the Sky Business Channel at seven

78.05.text:
o'clock each night, repeated at 9:30 just
in case you missed it. Now by the way, you

84.01.text:
can tell that I am not just a journalist,
I'm actually a small business owner, any chance

87.53.text:
to promote your business you will do it. But
in actual fact, I don't ever consider myself

93.90.text:
as a journalist, I'm a, I'm a method actor/journalist.
You know we have the switzer.com.au website,

102.55.text:
the Grow Your Business website, we have a
young woman's magazine called Rush. Rush is

108.03.text:
a very popular magazine. We have the Switzer
Super Report and we have a financial planning

112.37.text:
business and so we are right into small business,
we've got 45 staff members nowadays. So I

120.02.text:
really feel as though I know the beat. My
wife and I started the business many years

123.82.text:
ago and I know that a lot of small businesses
particularly in this State are couples. I

130.10.text:
know the success in business is invariably
related to those couples and a commitment

135.75.text:
to the goal that they started off with in
a dream and the people they take along on

139.99.text:
the journey. And my favourite story around
commitment I think is a real small business

144.25.text:
story of a couple and they were in business
for themselves and the husband was really

148.10.text:
feeling sick and he wouldn't go to the doctors
so eventually his wife made him go and she

152.59.text:
went with him to make sure he went and she
waited outside while he had the examination

156.36.text:
and when it was all over he walked out and
didn't say anything to his wife, went straight

159.24.text:
to the car. But she wasn't going to have that,
so she went straight into the doctor and said

162.83.text:
doctor can you tell me what my husband's prognosis
is, I'm really worried about him. And the

167.37.text:
doctor said you should be, I think your husband's
a candidate for a heart attack or stroke unless

171.17.text:
things change in his life. And she said well
I'm committed to helping him, what can I do?

175.38.text:
And he said great, well get up early each
morning, chop up fresh fruit, get yogurt into

179.49.text:
him, change his breakfast. When he comes home
from work let's have steamed fish and vegetables,

183.96.text:
change his lifestyle totally. But also while
he's under stress and I'm worried about him,

189.58.text:
could you try not to nag him because you know
I am worried about him. And also if you could

195.08.text:
could you try and have intimate moments with
him six or seven times a week. If you do that

200.94.text:
I think your husband can make it and she said
thanks very much doctor. So they were driving

204.29.text:
home and the husband looked at her and said
honey I saw you talking to the doctor you

207.42.text:
know what is my prognosis? And she looked
at him lovingly and said honey I don't think

211.67.text:
you're going to make it. We always have to
go the extra mile in small business and that's

218.07.text:
why I love it when a government tries to get
experts, people with insights to help build

225.70.text:
the competitive advantage and I know one of
the speakers today is certainly going to do

230.76.text:
that. So my role here of course is to keep
the show going but I also want to make the

237.60.text:
important point, Queensland's business quick
facts, small businesses employ about one million

242.21.text:
people. Brisbane has approximately 115,826
businesses and start ups. There are over 403,000

250.00.text:
small businesses in Queensland and small business
accounts for about 95 percent of all Queensland

255.62.text:
businesses. Over 220 events are being hosted
during the week including webinars, lunches,

261.82.text:
breakfasts, workshops and plenty of networking.
Today we're talking about when small businesses

267.85.text:
think big. And our keynote speaker certainly
has a big profile, Professor Josh Lerner joins

273.06.text:
us from the Harvard Business School in the
United States and we welcome him, I would

279.61.text:
love you to put your hands together for Josh
who's here. We should also thank the sponsors

287.63.text:
that make these sorts of event possible and
the gold sponsor is PwC and our silver sponsor

292.91.text:
is QUT Business School. They deserve a round
of applause as well. I now would like to call

302.53.text:
to the stage the Honourable Jann Stuckey,
the Minister for Tourism, Major Events, Small

306.37.text:
Business and the Commonwealth Games.
Thank you so much Peter, I actually told Peter

327.20.text:
last week I had to turn him down from going
on his show because I didn't have a voice

332.24.text:
but I do have it back pretty well this week
because I knew I'd be needing it for all of

339.34.text:
the wonderful events. Could I acknowledge
the Honourable Campbell Newman MP, the Premier

344.57.text:
of Queensland, Mr Mark Brennan, the Australian
Small Business Commissioner, Professor Josh

350.58.text:
Lerner who is the Professor for Investment
Banking at Harvard Business School and Head

355.91.text:
of Entrepreneurship Management Unit as well.
To Dr Richard Eden, the Director-General of

362.46.text:
my department, to my Queensland Small Business
Advisory Council members, to PricewaterhouseCoopers

368.54.text:
and again we thank you so much for being a
gold sponsor today. To all of the mentoring

374.03.text:
for growth mentor, members who are here today
thank you so much. And of course Peter, thank

380.76.text:
you for sharing with us your day time as well
of course those night time commentaries. Could

388.28.text:
I welcome everyone to City Hall. On behalf
of the State Government I'm really delighted

393.76.text:
to be able to host today's When Small Business
Thinks Big business leaders lunch. Now if

400.29.text:
you say that very quickly you get into a lot
of trouble. It does though officially welcome

406.45.text:
2014 Queensland Small Business Week. Last
year the inaugural 2013 Queensland Small Business

415.72.text:
Week featured 91 events and attracted more
than four and a half thousand participants.

423.67.text:
This year as you've heard from Peter, we have
actually over 240 events. They seem to be

431.05.text:
growing by the day as well as many other activities
being held right across the State. Now that's

437.71.text:
almost triple what we had last year. The week
provides a multitude of opportunities for

444.06.text:
small business owners and operators to network,
connect to new ideas and information, be motivated

450.59.text:
and celebrate the important contribution that
you make to Queensland's economy. It is vital

456.64.text:
that you all talk amongst yourselves, discuss
ideas and draw inspiration so that you can

464.28.text:
prosper and grow. And Queensland Small Business
Week provides the vehicle to do just that.

468.51.text:
The Premier and the rest of the LNP team are
unashamedly pro-small business because we

475.37.text:
understand that small business underpins our
Queensland economy. In fact it's the backbone

481.50.text:
of it. Like many of my government colleagues
I come from a small business background and

486.59.text:
I'm therefore thrilled to be hosting a number
of events not only in Brisbane but also the

492.41.text:
Sunshine and Gold Coasts and out in Roma later
this week. And could I add that I'm really

497.88.text:
pleased to see that not only a lot of small
businesses are here today but those from medium

503.27.text:
and large businesses as well. Everyone starts
small though don't they? Small businesses

508.81.text:
complement the economic activity of larger
organisations and are integral to your supply

513.85.text:
chains. And that is why it is so important
for all businesses to be thinking big but

520.35.text:
especially for small businesses looking at
taking that next step. As I've said there's

525.45.text:
heaps more activities in store. If you like
what you are seeing today I suggest that you

529.90.text:
engage in it a little bit more throughout
the week, go online to our business portal,

537.80.text:
www.business.qld.gov.au Small Business Week
and find out more. And it really does give

544.13.text:
me enormous pleasure to now introduce to the
stage Queensland Premier the Honourable Campbell

550.38.text:
Newman to speak to you further about small
business here in our great state.

565.85.text:
Well thanks very much Jann and good afternoon
ladies and gentlemen. It's a great pleasure

572.18.text:
to be here with so many people who make such
an important contribution to the economic

578.30.text:
lifeblood of Queensland. Can I acknowledge
the Turrbal and Jagera peoples, I acknowledge

583.60.text:
Jann Stuckey, my cabinet colleague, to Mark
Brennan, to Professor Josh Lerner, it's a

589.15.text:
great pleasure to see you here today sir and
we're really looking forward to what you have

593.21.text:
to say. I met Josh in New York back in March
this year. To Trevor Mahoney from PricewaterhouseCoopers,

599.32.text:
our gold sponsor and Professor Xavier from
Queensland University of Technology, our silver

604.70.text:
sponsor, but to you ladies and gentlemen thank
you so much for coming. Well I've got a speech

609.63.text:
here, it's the second speech today where I've
said the exact what I am about to say now

614.24.text:
and that is I don't like the speeches they've
given me today. So I am going to speak sort

618.12.text:
of from here and maybe a bit from here and
I'll see if I can well make, bring it all

622.20.text:
together and make sense. The first thing I
wanted to say to you is like me and my cabinet

627.11.text:
colleagues I've actually run a small business.
I've also been in a big business, I've also

632.32.text:
been in the public service, I've also been
in the military. So I can say to you having

637.64.text:
run a small business for two years, I really
absolutely get it and what's involved. And

642.50.text:
I've employed people and I know the challenges,
the responsibilities, but also the great sense

648.62.text:
of personal satisfaction when you do your
own thing. What I want to do very quickly

653.45.text:
though is talk about where the State's going.
And I am going to be quick because I'm not

657.01.text:
the main attraction today, it is Josh. So
I really have to race through this. The first

662.56.text:
thing I wanted to say is that we have a vision
for this State now that I think is incredibly

668.80.text:
exciting. It's not the government's vision,
it's the vision of 80,000 Queenslanders who

673.69.text:
had their say over the last 18 months to create
the Queensland Plan. Unlike any other State,

681.69.text:
unlike the Commonwealth Government this State
has a 30 year plan with goals and targets

689.63.text:
that very clearly sets out where we've got
to go and defines the Queensland that we want

696.32.text:
in the years to come. That's very powerful.
Now there are all range of things in there,

701.98.text:
it talks about education, it talks about health,
it talks about building up the regions, in

706.56.text:
fact it says that Queenslanders want to see
the population outside south east Queensland

712.62.text:
doubled over the next 30 years. That's a bold
an ambitious target. If you haven't seen the

718.61.text:
plan, I really encourage you to get hold of
it. Download it from the internet, it should

723.44.text:
be an invaluable business planning tool for
you because it talks about the real agenda.

728.69.text:
And all of government including local government
will be required to have regard to the Queensland

735.01.text:
Plan in all the things that we then do. One
of the aspects of course of the Queensland

740.64.text:
Plan is then need for a strong and vibrant
economy for jobs to be created. That's always

746.61.text:
been my government's agenda anyway. And we
have been working over the last two and a

751.40.text:
half years relentlessly to supercharge the
Queensland economy. So ladies and gentlemen

756.85.text:
we have been doing everything we can to make
this the best place in Australia to do business

763.39.text:
because we understand business, we know that
ultimately business takes care of itself if

770.44.text:
government gets out of the way. So we've had
a target to reduce red tape by 20 percent.

778.17.text:
We've been relentlessly going through and
looking at reform to get rid of needless red

783.35.text:
tape and bureaucracy. We got rid of a waste
tax, we changed the documentation for real

790.91.text:
estate agents selling homes. No longer do
small smash repairers and vehicle servicing

798.39.text:
garages have to have an environmental licence,
pay $1,500 and fill out forms each year. We've

807.30.text:
changed Worker's Compensation laws. We have
the best scheme in Australia now for employees

812.73.text:
ladies and gentlemen. It's the only state
where you're covered for journeys to and from

817.84.text:
work as an employee. However, on average Worker's
Compensation premiums have come down by 17

825.37.text:
percent for business in the new financial
year. There will be a lot more to come. I

832.21.text:
say today it's a thought for you for the future
through your representative organisations

837.17.text:
you need to let us know what more we, that
we can do. So Stephen Tate from CCIQ is here

842.61.text:
today for example. He sits in my business
advisory forum that meets quarterly and that

848.21.text:
is an opportunity always for business to say
get rid of this, change that, there are roadblocks

854.27.text:
there, how come you have that charge or tax,
wouldn't it be more efficient to do it that

858.74.text:
way? I assure you we really want to know this
stuff and we will continue to undertake reform

865.81.text:
that's sensible and makes sense. The exciting
thing though is where we are going now. If

871.40.text:
we go back three years ago this State was
in second last place in terms of the CommSec

877.73.text:
ratings of State's economic performance. We
were second only to Tasmania in terms of going

883.98.text:
for the wooden spoon, now we're in second
place. So we've moved up the ladder. And the

889.78.text:
exciting thing is, this financial year we
will go into lead place. We will be the lead

895.85.text:
State economically. This State is going to
see more jobs created, we are already doing

901.17.text:
that than any other Australian State each
month as we go forward. This State is going

906.66.text:
to see continued growth in construction, in
tourism, in agriculture and yes in resources.

914.74.text:
And the small businesses that support all
those sectors will continue to prosper. And

919.93.text:
of course international student education,
biotechnology and IT, the gains industry still

925.74.text:
continue I think to grow successfully. Before
I conclude, I just wanted to talk about one

931.61.text:
other thing that is very important to us that
you may not have heard of. We believe ladies

936.80.text:
and gentlemen in a very important principle
and the principle is what we call open data.

943.13.text:
What I'm talking about is this, government
collects all sorts of information but it's

949.77.text:
never released it in the past. Today you can
go to the open data website and there's some,

955.43.text:
some 1,400 data sets that we now have put
out there, information, data that has never

961.31.text:
been available before that you can use for
your business, all sorts of stuff. Some of

966.43.text:
its seemingly useless and superfluous, but
for example you can see the location of any

972.01.text:
bus stop in the State. You can see where the
schools are. You can find out what motor vehicles

979.77.text:
are registered by various make and model in
the suburbs and the cities in towns of Queensland.

986.39.text:
You can see real time updated every 30 minutes
where every bushfire in Queensland is or every

992.52.text:
authorised controlled burn. Now you might
say why is he going on about this? Well ladies

998.23.text:
and gentlemen data information is gold. That's
why we are also this week launching our open

1007.06.text:
data competition so that application developers,
data miners, business people can propose great

1014.79.text:
ideas about how to use this data for economic
advantage. Ladies and gentlemen this is an

1020.41.text:
exciting time to live in this State. This
year we will become the lead economic State

1025.58.text:
and I urge all small businesses to see that,
realise that, seize the opportunities and

1032.21.text:
take the potential of this State forward.
You do employ 38 percent of the workshop,

1037.18.text:
workforce across 403,000 businesses. If every
small business employed one or two more people

1043.70.text:
just think what we'd see in terms of our jobs
figures. Thank you very much for coming today,

1049.00.text:
again I am looking forward with keen anticipation
to Professor Lerner's speech. It's great to

1055.04.text:
have you here Josh. And with those few words
I just say ladies and gentlemen it's great

1059.33.text:
pleasure to official declare Small Business
Week 2014 open, thank you.

1071.87.text:
Thank you Premier, I would now like to welcome
today's special guest the Australian Small

1075.93.text:
Business Commissioner Mark Brennan.
Thank you Peter and thank you to everyone

1092.06.text:
for the opportunity of being here today with
you and to welcome you to this terrific event.

1097.86.text:
I'd like to acknowledge the Honourable Campbell
Newman, the Premier of the State of Queensland,

1104.70.text:
the Minister for Tourism, Major Events, Small
Business and the Commonwealth Games, Jann

1110.78.text:
Stuckey, Professor Lerner, it's great to see
that you have come over to join us today and

1116.65.text:
all small business people of Queensland, welcome.
I think it's quite fitting that today that

1124.22.text:
I'm actually following the Premier because
he finished off talking about the importance

1130.18.text:
of data and he said data is gold. Well my
office, the office of the Australian Small

1135.34.text:
Business Commissioner has a catchcry which
says no small business should fail through

1140.89.text:
lack of access to information. So information,
data, they're the keystones. They're the things

1147.95.text:
that governments for example have a core responsibility
for to ensure that information is available,

1154.04.text:
accessible for businesses to be able to utilise
in order to prosper in the business environment

1161.15.text:
that's created. So that's a key message that
our office puts out is be hungry for information.

1169.15.text:
We also in our role look at helping businesses
sort out problems they've got with other businesses

1174.95.text:
or problems they've got with government agencies.
And we do this very much by encouraging people

1180.17.text:
to seek to have matters mediated rather than
going through traditional and expensive and

1185.14.text:
stressful court processes. The other functions
which we have is to be an advocate to government,

1192.05.text:
to inform government about what we've sort
of seen as the coal face of the problems that

1198.04.text:
are facing small businesses, and also to be
an advocate to the business community itself.

1205.87.text:
And in that regard we've got what I call our
overarching aspirations and that is that every

1212.36.text:
participant in the business community can
lift their game. There's scope for every participant

1218.70.text:
in the business community to get better at
what they do. And in terms of participants

1223.33.text:
here I'm talking about big business, government
agencies, media, academics, regulators, industry

1234.21.text:
and professional associations and small businesses
themselves. And I'll just share a couple of

1239.17.text:
thoughts about each of those. Big business,
there's tremendous scope for big business

1244.53.text:
to show leadership to the small business community
and it is very refreshing to see PricewaterhouseCoopers

1250.35.text:
having such a, a role with Small Business
Week. Government agencies, again I found refreshing

1256.59.text:
something which the Premier has said about
his own experiences in small business because

1262.03.text:
too often you find that those in government
who are influencing the business environment

1266.03.text:
have never actually played the game of business
and coming from Victoria and Australian Rules

1272.39.text:
State, one of the greatest insults you can
say to somebody is you are like an umpire

1277.45.text:
who's never played the game. And I think we
find that at a number of levels of government

1282.94.text:
that you are getting people who are influencing
the business environment and yet they don't

1286.44.text:
know how hard it is to get a kick in the game
of small business. And so it's very refreshing

1291.39.text:
to hear of people who have, who are in this
position of being able to look at what sort

1295.78.text:
of interventions there should be from government
and they have actually played the game themselves.

1300.83.text:
So we look to encourage government agencies
to get better at what they do by understanding

1304.82.text:
more about what the game of small business
is all about. The media and it's good to see

1310.56.text:
Peter here today too, I think he may well
agree with me that there are lots of opportunities

1316.02.text:
for the media to be more balanced and positive
in the way in which they report on or investigate

1323.23.text:
the business community. And we'd like to see
the media look at opportunities to lift its

1328.53.text:
game as well. Academics and Professor Lerner
and also a, very happy to see Queensland University

1336.39.text:
of Technology is a sponsor here because with
academics I think there's scope for academics

1342.01.text:
to be more practical in their research at,
or come up with practical solutions with their

1348.16.text:
research activities. And I did notice that
one of the objectives of the Queensland University

1352.60.text:
of Technology is to attempt to try to make
that connect between research and practice

1359.00.text:
and I encourage academics to be more centred
that way of undertaking the research but also

1365.86.text:
looking to see well is a government going
to adopt this as a policy, is a practitioner

1370.02.text:
going to actually put any of my research into
practice to assist the way in which they run

1375.43.text:
their business. Industry and professional
associations and again Stephen Tate, nice

1379.31.text:
to see you here today, again I here that there's
great scope for these associations to get

1387.59.text:
better at what they do, to not just be a lobbyist
to government but also to be of real service

1392.49.text:
to their members. I did start by saying about
access to information being so important,

1397.81.text:
well industry and professional associations
are a tremendous medium for that. Regulators,

1403.97.text:
and this is one of my soapboxes, regulators,
I really do think that regulators can contribute

1409.44.text:
much more constructively to the business environment
than what they do. It's easy and it's lazy

1416.08.text:
to be a regulator who's a crackdown, clamp
down regulator. I think the business community

1420.82.text:
responds far more positively to a facilitative
approach to regulation and I encourage regulators

1427.29.text:
to look at ways of educating to comply rather
than running up figures of infringements and

1433.02.text:
cracking down on people. And then finally
small businesses themselves, all small business

1439.35.text:
has got scope to get better at what they do.
We encourage small business to be hungry for

1445.09.text:
information. Getting back to where I started
about seeking access to information, well

1450.22.text:
be hungry for information. Want to know more
about how you can improve your business. And

1455.08.text:
that's the encouragement that we give to the
small business community itself. Thank you

1459.01.text:
again for the opportunity to be here. Welcome
to everybody, it's a great initiative, I really

1463.49.text:
do commend the Queensland Government for putting
on Queensland Small Business Week. I'm sure

1468.03.text:
it's going to be a terrific success. Thank
you.

1476.92.text:
Thank you Mark. And a very important role
you play as well. We're going to serve our

1482.22.text:
main course now but before we go I think the
important lesson is that, and it came out

1487.61.text:
in Mark's speech in particular and also the
Premier's is that we in small business have

1491.55.text:
to be on the lookout for things that will
make a difference in our business. And invariably

1496.29.text:
it's us looking at ourselves and being objective
about what we can do to lift our game. In

1501.83.text:
many cases people find it very difficult to
be objective. Me personally I was really lucky.

1507.48.text:
I married someone who actually decided to
become my life coach voluntarily and Maureen

1515.72.text:
decided that she would look at me on a daily
basis and tell me what's wrong with me. But

1521.43.text:
more importantly she told me what I could
do to fix it. Hence the reason why our business

1527.71.text:
has done so well and it's why I always say
behind every successful man is a very surprised

1533.38.text:
woman. Okay, I'll be back in a moment to introduce
Josh Lerner.

1534.38.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attention.
I hope you are enjoying your lunch, beautiful

1535.38.text:
Queensland food. Queensland's a State renowned
for its diverse and innovative business community.

1539.48.text:
Research has shown that business inv-, sentiment
is high and Queensland is positioned well

1544.56.text:
to build to our competitive strengths. But
what is happening beyond our local economy

1550.61.text:
is Queensland's entrepreneurial drive and
determination translating to results on a
